title: Build-Measure-Learn Feedback Loop
summary: A core process in Lean Startup for turning ideas into products, measuring customer response, and learning whether to pivot or persevere.

details.content: This loop ensures that startups focus on learning what customers actually want, rather than what founders think they want, minimizing wasted effort and resources.
A team quickly builds a prototype, releases it to a small group of users, collects feedback on usability, and uses the insights to improve the next version.

content: Start with a clear hypothesis to test.
Build the simplest version of your idea.
Measure user behavior and feedback objectively.
Analyze results to decide next steps.
Repeat the loop rapidly for faster learning.

title: Minimum Viable Product (MVP)
summary: The simplest version of a product that allows a team to collect the maximum amount of validated learning about customers with the least effort.

details.content: Building an MVP prevents over-investing in features that customers may not want, enabling faster feedback and iteration.
Launching a landing page to gauge interest in a new service before developing the full product.

content: Identify the core value proposition.
Strip away non-essential features.
Release early to real users.
Use feedback to guide further development.
Don’t aim for perfection—focus on learning.

title: Validated Learning
summary: A process of demonstrating empirically that a team has discovered valuable truths about a startup’s present and future business prospects.

details.content: Validated learning helps teams avoid assumptions and base decisions on real data, reducing risk and uncertainty.
Running an experiment to test whether users will pay for a new feature, and using the results to decide on further investment.

content: Formulate clear, testable hypotheses.
Design experiments to gather actionable data.
Measure outcomes objectively.
Document learnings and share with the team.
Iterate based on what you learn.

title: Pivot or Persevere
summary: A decision point in the Lean Startup process where a team decides whether to make a fundamental change to the product or strategy (pivot) or keep improving on the current path (persevere).

details.content: Regularly evaluating progress ensures that resources are not wasted on ideas that aren’t working, and that teams are responsive to real-world feedback.
After several iterations, a startup finds that users are not engaging with a feature and decides to pivot to a new approach based on user feedback.

content: Set clear metrics for success.
Review progress at regular intervals.
Be honest about what’s working and what isn’t.
Don’t be afraid to make bold changes if needed.
Communicate decisions clearly to the team.

title: Innovation Accounting
summary: A system for measuring progress, setting up milestones, and prioritizing work when developing innovative products.

details.content: Traditional accounting doesn’t capture the learning and progress of startups; innovation accounting provides relevant metrics for early-stage ventures.
Tracking metrics like customer acquisition cost, activation rate, and retention instead of just revenue in the early stages.

content: Define actionable metrics tied to learning goals.
Avoid vanity metrics that don’t drive decisions.
Set clear milestones for learning and growth.
Review metrics regularly to guide pivots or perseverance.
Align team incentives with learning milestones.

title: Continuous Deployment
summary: A practice of releasing small, frequent updates to a product, allowing for rapid iteration and immediate feedback.

details.content: Continuous deployment reduces the time between idea and customer feedback, enabling faster learning and adaptation.
A software team automatically deploys code changes to production several times a day, quickly fixing bugs and testing new features.

content: Automate testing and deployment processes.
Release small, incremental changes.
Monitor user feedback and system performance.
Roll back quickly if issues arise.
Foster a culture of experimentation and learning.

title: Split Testing
summary: A method of comparing two or more versions of a product or feature to determine which performs better with real users.

details.content: Split testing provides objective data on user preferences and behavior, guiding product decisions and reducing guesswork.
Testing two different landing page designs to see which one results in more sign-ups.

content: Test one variable at a time for clear results.
Ensure sample sizes are large enough for statistical significance.
Use clear, measurable goals for each test.
Analyze results objectively and act on findings.
Document and share learnings with the team.
